comment.narrative:
Key results of the project.
Despite of early planning and timely start of activities in the fields, the restrictions imposed by the government, due to COVID-19 pandemic, and limitations for movement of project personnel between regions had some impact on the overall implementation and progress of the project. The main challenges faced by the project during the first six months of pandemic were unavailability of required specialists and local authorities for meetings and discussions, due to overload on their workplaces by government instructions and countermeasures on pandemic. Plus, the imposed restrictions for movement and gathering people for meetings also limited the project’s activities in the fields. Although, these limitations delayed implementation or completion of some activities, they did not significantly affect the overall results of the project. The project continued implementation of its activities remotely, where and when it was possible.
In cooperation with the State Plants Quarantine Inspection, the project successfully completed installation and created a network of 9 agrometeorological stations (T-Warner 300) in target districts of Fergana Valley, which provides meteorological data and forecasts, including forecasts of disease and pests’ outbreaks in target areas.
In addition, the project with support of national experts from Inha University in Tashkent and Tashkent State Agrarian University developed a local prototype of agrometeorological station and its software for provision of agrometeorological data, weather and disease/pests outbreaks forecasts for end-users. 6 local prototypes were assembled and installed in target districts of the project and currently are being tested in the fields.
Furthermore, the project mobilized USD 280,000 from UNDP’s COVID-19 response package for Uzbekistan for supporting agricultural cooperatives from remote rural areas affected by COVID-19 crisis. Through mobilized additional funding the project is planning to support and provide technical assistance to 7 agricultural cooperatives/agroclusters in mitigating negative impacts of pandemic through creation of new workplaces for vulnerable groups, women and youth. The pilot sites in Andijan and Fergana regions, where agrometeorological stations have been installed, were visited by the CCI Chairman, UNDP RR, Head of the State Plants Quarantine Inspection, Minister of the Agriculture, Head of the Council of Farmers, districts hokims to review and get acquainted with the work of the project and the stations, including services provided by the Inspection specialists to nearby farmers within the framework of cooperation with the project.
Result 1. 1. A survey of impact of climate change on agricultural production has been conducted among farmers from target districts. More than 90 respondents from the agricultural sector took part in the online survey, of which 17.4% are women, 82.6% are men and 30% are youth. The results of the survey have been incorporated to the assessment on impact of climate change on agricultural sector of Fergana Valley, which was developed by the project at the end of 2019. 2. The recommendations on improvement of soil and water management, and use of biological pest control methods have been included to respective sectors of the Concept of development of Namangan region for 2020-2030. 3. The Concept of Namangan region development for 2020-2030, including a Roadmap of implementation of the Concept for 2020-2022 have been revised and updated by the team of local experts consisting from representatives of regional administrative office (Hokimiyat), economic planning, finance, agricultural sector and other departments. The data and statistics for 2019 and 2020 years have been included to the Concept and some planned activities and tasks have been revised and updated. 4. More than 117 people (30 women) consisting from representatives of farmers-gardeners, local government, agricultural institutions, entrepreneurs and dekhkan farms improved their knowledge on climate change and adaptation measures through 3 seminars conducted in target regions of Fergana Valley. 5. The concept on Integrated Pest Management (IPM) has been developed, which includes the approach and measures on integration with the agrometeorological stations installed by project in pilot districts. The Concept has been shared with specialists of the State Plants Quarantine Inspection, which will be responsible for testing and implementation of the IPM methodology. 6. Minimum 5 recommendations have been developed and shared with the team of experts engaged in development of the Concept of Namangan region development. 7. 5 discussion-meetings and 1 survey on IT-tools usage were conducted with representatives of Departments for Innovation, Economy and Agriculture, Statistics, as well as other agriculture related departments. During the meetings, the initial version of the IT tool concept was presented and recommendations on improvement of the electronic platform were obtained. In addition, a survey has been conducted among representatives of agrarian, statistical and informatization sectors. Based on data and recommendations obtained during the survey, the concept of the ICT platform is being modified and finalized. The process of development of the IT tool will be started upon final agreement of the concept with all stakeholders.
Result 2. 1. The partnership agreement has been signed with the State Plants Quarantine Inspection for establishing extension centers and the network of agrometeorological stations for provision of agrometeorological data, weather and disease/pests’ outbreaks forecasts and recommendations for effective agricultural production. 3 agroconsulting centers in 3 regions of FV have been established and equipped in partnership with the Inspection. 2. Draft analysis on current situation of agricultural insurance sector has been prepared and infographic on agroinsurance has been developed. The existing problems in agroinsurance sector were studied and recommendations developed based on international practices in this sector. The document has been shared with CO for review and feedback. 3. 7 business projects have been selected through competitive process for technical and financial support by the project. The supported business projects will enable better or new employment opportunities for approx. 300 people, mostly women and youth from rural areas. All requested equipment have been procured and installed, and contributions of business initiators at the ratio of 30/70 (with major part of initiators) have been ensured by the project. In addition, $280,000 USD secured from COVID-19 RR project and additional 7 business projects have been selected for project support. Procurement process of the requested equipment has been launched and commercial offers of potential vendors are being evaluated. 4. More than 680 employment opportunities for rural population, including 240 low-income families, 185 women and 15 youth, will be created within 14 business projects selected within the framework of the project for support and technical assistance. 5. The cooperation agreement on establishment of the network of extension centers with the system of agrometeorological stations has been signed with the State Plants Quarantine Inspection. Within the framework of this agreement a network comprising 15 agrometeorological stations has been established and 9 Telegram groups were created, where weather, disease and pest forecasts and recommendations are being provided by the specialists of the Inspection. More than 340 user-farmers are currently using this information for improvement their agricultural practices, volume and quality of their produce. In addition, a local prototype of agrometeorological station and its disease/pests forecasting software have been designed and developed by national experts. 5 new local stations have been assembled and 1 existing station has been upgraded. All local stations are currently being tested for accuracy of models and forecasts. 6. More than 530 representatives (100 women) of regional authorities, agroindustry sector, CCI, Farmers Council, quarantine departments and farmers increased their knowledge and skills during the 5 thematic seminars and 2 webinars on certification and standardization of fruits and vegetables, business planning and marketing, climate change and adaptation measures, agrotechnical measures and preparation of gardens for the spring season, protection of plants from common types of pests and diseases, role of weather stations in forecasting and controlling pests and diseases, etc.

Key results of the project.
The project office in Namangan has been established and fully equipped at the premises of the regional office of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry. More than 65 mln. UZS has been secured from the project partner for renovation of the project office.
9 target districts from three regions of Fergana Valley have been selected according to the selection criteria developed and agreed with the national partner of the project. The following target districts have been selected in consultation with the regional administrative offices (Hokimiyats): 1. Andijan region - Andijan, Asaka and Hujaabad districts; 2. Fergana region - Altiariq, Quva and Quvasay districts; 3. Namangan region - Chartak, Chust and Yangikurgan districts.
3 introductory seminars/launch events have been conducted in three regions of Fergana Valley to inform the beneficiaries about the project and introduce objectives and planned activities within the project.
21 meetings were held with representatives of regional authorities, agencies and organizations to inform them about the project and discuss opportunities for cooperation within the framework of the project.
Result 1. 1. Draft assessment on impact of climate change on agricultural sector of Fergana Valley has been developed by a research team of national experts. 2. Recommendations on consideration of climate risks in development of agricultural sector have been developed by the research team and shared with a team of national experts engaged in development of the Concept of Namangan region development for 2020-2030. 3. A Research Center "Scientific bases and issues of economic development of Uzbekistan" has been contracted to develop a Concept of Namangan region development for 2020-2030, including a Roadmap of implementation of the Concept for 2020-2022. In addition, a team of local experts consisting from representatives of regional administrative office (Hokimiyat), economic planning, finance, agricultural sector and other departments has been formed. The existing Regional Development Strategy of Namangan region has been shared with both teams for the review. 4. Elaboration of the Concept on integrated pest management is on process. Planned to be completed in 2020. 5. Minimum 5 recommendations have been developed and shared with the the team of experts engaged in development of the Concept of Namangan region development. 6. The consultations on IT tools development for agro-planners were held with representatives of regional administrative offices (Hokimiyats). The identification of appropriate IT tool that will be further adopted by the regional administrative offices is not finalized. The experience of other neighboring and developed countries is being studied for further recommendation to decision makers.
Result 2. 1. The study on benefits of application of agrometeorological stations in horticulture and strengthening of extension services has been conducted by the national expert. The international and national experience have been explored and recommendations on setting up of agrometeorology stations system for provision of climate related information and extension services have been developed. 2. The selection criteria of potential organizations have been developed for support/establishment of agricultural advisory services (extension services) throughout Fergana Valley. 3. 9 meetings were held with representatives of regional departments of the Council of Farmers, Quarantine inspections and Agrokimyohimoya to identify their potential and interest in cooperation with the project. 4. Based on the results of the study of potential regional organizations, the State Plants Quarantine Inspection under the Cabinet of Ministers of the Republic of Uzbekistan has been selected for cooperation with the project and development of extension services, including establishment of a network of agro-meteorological stations to provide timely information and recommendations to farmers in target districts of Fergana Valley. 5. 9 agro-meteorological stations (T-Warner 300) were procured from STEP Systems GmbH for installation in target districts of the project. 6. The criteria and procedure for selecting business ideas to support agro-producers were developed and approved, including simplified application forms and a business plan for presentation by the initiators. The criteria and application forms distributed among potential farmers and entrepreneurs during information meetings and seminars. 7. 578 representatives (78 women) of regional authorities, agroindustry sector, CCI, Farmers Council, quarantine departments and farmers increased their knowledge and skills during the 3 thematic and practical seminars on preparations of orchards and vineyards to winter season, and benefits and role of agrometeorological stations in pest and disease control.
